docs.lead_paragraph: On a weekday afternoon in 1992, Sunny Cloud, an insurance saleswoman and single mother in Marietta, Ga., dropped by her home unexpectedly and found her 16-year-old son, Ron, smoking marijuana. Stunned, Ms. Cloud hustled the boy off to the nearest hospital emergency room, where she asked doctors to screen his urine. ''I was scared,'' she said recently, ''and I didn't know what else to do.''
docs.abstract: Growing number of companies are marketing test kits with which they say parents can learn if their children are smoking marijuana or taking illicit; they can cite the steady rise in illicit teen-age drug use over past six years and offer their products as lifelines for parents struggling to keep their teen-agers away from drugs; critics warn that tests will turn parents into detectives, undermining the fragile trust essential in guiding children through teen-age years; say worried parents should be talking with their children instead of relying on tests that can produce false results; graph; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the legendary women's films of the 30's and 40's, much-loved throb specialists like Bette Davis, Margaret Sullavan, Joan Crawford and Barbara Stanwyck played gallantly miserable women in stories where love was a vocation with its own rules and heroics. Vexed relationships and outsize emotions claimed center stage, and the tears they generated provided catharsis for female moviegoers who felt trapped by fate and domesticity. The genre, revolving as it does around a sense of limited options, would seem to have outlived its raison d'etre in the rush of women's new-found freedoms. We supposedly live in a liberated era of multiple choices, high-powered careers, chic out-of-wedlock pregnancies and serial marriage. Yet here, in modified form, is the woman's film staging a comeback, suggesting at the very least that our horizons are narrower and our options fewer than we think.

headline.main: A Touch of the 1940's Woman in the 90's

docs.abstract: Molly Haskell article recounts legendary women's films of 1930's and 1940's in light of new ones, including Stepmom, One True Thing and The Theory of Flight; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN San Diego on Tuesday, two major drug companies rolled out studies showing the safety and effectiveness of a new class of prescription pain relievers; they had been duly tested on thousands of patients, some for up to a year. Such testing was a minimum requirement before the drugs could be prescribed to millions of Americans. If the Food and Drug Administration approves, the drugs can be sold. On the same day, the prestigious Journal of the American Medical Association held a news conference in Washington to hail the publication of six papers ''evaluating'' studies of alternative medical treatments.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; The Herbal Potions That Make Science Sick

docs.abstract: Alternative medical treatment is becoming a contentious issue among the medical community, especially following recent report in Journal of American Medical Association and accompanying editorial that supported the publication of six papers 'evaluating' studies of alternative medical treatments; treatments were already on the market and studies came after the fact; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Noel-Ann d'Ablemont, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. d'Ablemont of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Douglas Patrick Smith, a son of Katherine M. Hering of Savannah, Ga., and Cornelius C. Smith Jr. of New Milford, Conn. John Cardinal O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. Mrs. d'Ablemont-Smith, 32, is the manager of marketing and sales at Globe Tax Services, a financial services company in New York. She graduated from Trinity College in Washington. Her father is a partner in Kelley, Drye & Warren, a law firm in New York. Her mother, Mary d'Ablemont, is the chairwoman of the Pregnancy Care Center and the Elinor Martin Residence for Mother and Child at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains.
